title: SLASH
data:
**SLASH** (SuperLotsaAddedStuffHack) is a [variant](/wiki/Variant "Variant") of [NetHack 3.1.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.1.3 "NetHack 3.1.3"), later updated to [NetHack 3.2.2](/wiki/NetHack_3.2.2 "NetHack 3.2.2"). It initially combined [NetHack-- 3.1.3](/wiki/NetHack--_3.1.3 "NetHack-- 3.1.3") with [NetHack Plus](/wiki/NetHack_Plus "NetHack Plus"). The subsequent addition of the [Wizard Patch](/wiki/Wizard_Patch "Wizard Patch") produced [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM").

## Releases

Tom Proudfoot, who originally created [NetHack-- 3.0.10](/wiki/NetHack--_3.0.10 "NetHack-- 3.0.10"), released six versions of SLASH:

| Release                      | Date        | Announcement                                                                      |
| ---------------------------- | ----------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| 1                            | 16 Feb 1996 | <http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/02b045fd0ee23617> |
| 2                            | 18 Feb 1996 | <http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/08dd23d68e9ec9c3> |
| 3                            | 26 Feb 1996 | <http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/352a04d084041eb2> |
| 4                            | 8 Mar 1996  | <http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/1097aef0a2834cd2> |
| 5                            | 17 Mar 1996 | <http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/a830d3af60b1ad69> |
| [6](/wiki/SLASH_6 "SLASH 6") | 30 Mar 1996 | <http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/768bbab37d7e6072> |

[SLASH 6](/wiki/SLASH_6 "SLASH 6") is archived at Ali Harlow's website [here](http://www.juiblex.co.uk/nethack/source/slashsr6.zip). Other versions may be found in various dusty corners of the Web.

[NetHack 3.2.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.2.0 "NetHack 3.2.0") was released on 18 April 1996 and Tom Proudfoot released no more versions of SLASH. Enrico Horn later resumed development, releasing a SLASH based on [NetHack 3.2.1](/wiki/NetHack_3.2.1 "NetHack 3.2.1") on [8 October 1996](http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/cfe160b3c23ab490). The last version, called SLASH 4.1.2-8, was a merge with [NetHack 3.2.2](/wiki/NetHack_3.2.2 "NetHack 3.2.2").

Enrico Horn's website has disappeared, but is still visible on the [Wayback Machine](http://web.archive.org/) [here](https://web.archive.org/web/20001210111500/http://www.rz.tu-ilmenau.de/~wi019/Slash.html). As the DOS source archives found there are unfortunately truncated, interested parties should download the [Unix patch](https://web.archive.org/web/20001210111500/http://www.rz.tu-ilmenau.de/~wi019/Slash/Slash-Unix.tar.gz) instead. This tarball should be unpacked into the top directory of a clean [NetHack 3.2.2](/wiki/NetHack_3.2.2 "NetHack 3.2.2") source tree; it will unpack into new files and two patches. If only the first patch is applied, the resulting tree is in agreement with the recoverable parts of the DOS archive.

## Legacy

The [Wizard Patch](/wiki/Wizard_Patch "Wizard Patch") proved popular, and in time Warren Cheung ported it to SLASH, calling the resulting game SLASH'EM, the EM part meaning Extended Magic. He released it on [7 January 1998](https://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/21fc87c895373907). SLASH and SLASH'EM coexisted for the rest of the 3.2.2 era.

[NetHack 3.3.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.3.0 "NetHack 3.3.0") accepted the Wizard Patch into the mainline code. SLASH'EM 0.0.5E8 merged in the 3.3.0 code, and consequently SLASH ceased to exist as a separate game from SLASH'EM.

[![This article may require revision for the next version of SLASH'EM. Click here for more information.](/images/3/38/Se7e7-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article may require revision for the next version of SLASH'EM. Click here for more information.")
html:
SLASH

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

SLASH (SuperLotsaAddedStuffHack) is a variant of NetHack 3.1.3, later updated to NetHack 3.2.2. It initially combined NetHack-- 3.1.3 with NetHack Plus. The subsequent addition of the Wizard Patch produced SLASH'EM.

Releases

Tom Proudfoot, who originally created NetHack-- 3.0.10, released six versions of SLASH:

Release Date Announcement
1 16 Feb 1996 http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/02b045fd0ee23617
2 18 Feb 1996 http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/08dd23d68e9ec9c3
3 26 Feb 1996 http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/352a04d084041eb2
4 8 Mar 1996 http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/1097aef0a2834cd2
5 17 Mar 1996 http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/a830d3af60b1ad69
6 30 Mar 1996 http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/768bbab37d7e6072

SLASH 6 is archived at Ali Harlow's website here. Other versions may be found in various dusty corners of the Web.

NetHack 3.2.0 was released on 18 April 1996 and Tom Proudfoot released no more versions of SLASH. Enrico Horn later resumed development, releasing a SLASH based on NetHack 3.2.1 on 8 October 1996. The last version, called SLASH 4.1.2-8, was a merge with NetHack 3.2.2.

Enrico Horn's website has disappeared, but is still visible on the Wayback Machine here. As the DOS source archives found there are unfortunately truncated, interested parties should download the Unix patch instead. This tarball should be unpacked into the top directory of a clean NetHack 3.2.2 source tree; it will unpack into new files and two patches. If only the first patch is applied, the resulting tree is in agreement with the recoverable parts of the DOS archive.

Legacy

The Wizard Patch proved popular, and in time Warren Cheung ported it to SLASH, calling the resulting game SLASH'EM, the EM part meaning Extended Magic. He released it on 7 January 1998. SLASH and SLASH'EM coexisted for the rest of the 3.2.2 era.

NetHack 3.3.0 accepted the Wizard Patch into the mainline code. SLASH'EM 0.0.5E8 merged in the 3.3.0 code, and consequently SLASH ceased to exist as a separate game from SLASH'EM.

Retrieved from "https://nethackwiki.com/index.php?title=SLASH&oldid=177324"

rawPage:
'''SLASH''' (SuperLotsaAddedStuffHack) is a [[variant]] of [[NetHack 3.1.3]], later updated to [[NetHack 3.2.2]]. It initially combined [[NetHack-- 3.1.3]] with [[NetHack Plus]].  The subsequent addition of the [[Wizard Patch]] produced [[SLASH'EM]].

== Releases ==

Tom Proudfoot, who originally created [[NetHack-- 3.0.10]], released six versions of SLASH:

{|class="wikitable"
!Release!!Date!!Announcement
|-
|1|| 16 Feb 1996 || http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/02b045fd0ee23617
|-
|2|| 18 Feb 1996 || http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/08dd23d68e9ec9c3
|-

|-

|-
|5|| 17 Mar 1996 ||http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/a830d3af60b1ad69
|-
|[[SLASH 6|6]]|| 30 Mar 1996 || http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/768bbab37d7e6072
|}

[[SLASH 6]] is archived at Ali Harlow's website [http://www.juiblex.co.uk/nethack/source/slashsr6.zip here]. Other versions may be found in various dusty corners of the Web.

[[NetHack 3.2.0]] was released on 18 April 1996 and Tom Proudfoot released no more versions of SLASH. Enrico Horn later resumed development, releasing a SLASH based on [[NetHack 3.2.1]] on [http://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/cfe160b3c23ab490 8 October 1996]. The last version, called SLASH 4.1.2-8, was a merge with [[NetHack 3.2.2]].

Enrico Horn's website has disappeared, but is still visible on the [http://web.archive.org/ Wayback Machine] [https://web.archive.org/web/20001210111500/http://www.rz.tu-ilmenau.de/~wi019/Slash.html here]. As the DOS source archives found there are unfortunately truncated, interested parties should download the [https://web.archive.org/web/20001210111500/http://www.rz.tu-ilmenau.de/~wi019/Slash/Slash-Unix.tar.gz Unix patch] instead.  This tarball should be unpacked into the top directory of a clean [[NetHack 3.2.2]] source tree; it will unpack into new files and two patches. If only the first patch is applied, the resulting tree is in agreement with the recoverable parts of the DOS archive.

==Legacy==
The [[Wizard Patch]] proved popular, and in time Warren Cheung ported it to SLASH, calling the resulting game SLASH'EM, the EM part meaning Extended Magic.  He released it on [https://groups.google.com/group/rec.games.roguelike.nethack/msg/21fc87c895373907 7 January 1998]. SLASH and SLASH'EM coexisted for the rest of the 3.2.2 era.

[[NetHack 3.3.0]] accepted the Wizard Patch into the mainline code. SLASH'EM 0.0.5E8 merged in the 3.3.0 code, and consequently SLASH ceased to exist as a separate game from SLASH'EM.
